journal-meta.journal-title: The International Journal of Lower Extremity Wounds

title-group.subtitle: Lymphedema Is Not a Problem That Will Go Away if Ignored

author-notes.corresp: Miltos K. Lazarides, Department of Vascular Surgery, Democritus University Hospital, Alexandroupolis 68100, Greece Email: mlazarid@med.duth.gr

body.p: Lymphedema is a scarcely reported issue in vascular literature. A search of the past 3 years’ issues (2009-2011) in 2 leading vascular surgery journals from both sides of the Atlantic, namely the Journal of Vascular Surgery and the European Journal of Vascular and Endovascular Surgery and additional search in the angiologists’ journal International Angiology revealed only 12 articles dealing with lymphedema.1-12 These few articles represent only 0.5% of the total number of articles published in these journals in those 3 years. Interestingly, all these articles were devoted to either the primary lymphedema being mostly congenital or to upper limb secondary lymphedema following breast cancer, ignoring the most frequent type of secondary lymphedema caused by lymphatic filiarasis. The latter is endemic in sub-Saharan Africa, India, and areas of Latin America, and it is estimated that more than 120 million people are infected.13

IJLEW wishes to devote a special issue to lymphedema recognizing that this entity if left untreated may lead to specific complications such as recurrent cellulitis or nonhealed wounds representing 2.6% of the total number of those attending a wound management clinic.14

This issue has contributions from several experts not only focusing on the “Western” types lymphedema but also on those types common in the Third World, of interest to all physicians as immigration increases such sporadic cases in Europe and the United States. It should interest all to note that the UK National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE) in its guidelines related to liposuction states that key efficacy outcomes should include (a) reduction in limb volume and swelling, (b) patient comfort, (c) patient satisfaction, and (d) quality of life and lymphatic function. It further states that “long-term benefits of liposuction compared with optimal compression regimes remain unknown.”15 This message is important to clinician researchers; the availability and suitability of elasticated compression regimes in all countries as well as simple measurements of limb volumes are essential topics of research in these areas.
